articleinfo.title: Orocos Toolchain &version; Release Series Changes, New Features, and Fixes

article.para: This document provides a quick overview of what changed between the Orocos Toolchain &oldversion; and version &version;.

Please consult the online wiki for all available information about the 1.x to 2.x transition: The Road to RTT 2.0. The Real-Time Toolkit is no longer released as a single entity, but as part of a complete set of tools and libraries for creating real-time applications. See also the Toolchain 2.0 Changes.

listitem.para: This release is binary incompatible with RTT &oldversion;.x. You need to upgrade and recompile all your applications in order to use this release.
On Linux, the 2.0.x releases loaded every plugin or component library which filename had ".so" in it. This version only loads libraries ending in ".so".

You can now use the 'autoproj' tool to download, build and update the Orocos Toolchain. Bootstrapping is done with the 'bootstrap.sh' file, which will install autoproj and all Orocos libraries. See the Quick Start wiki.

You no longer need a FindOrocosRTT.cmake file to detect the RTT and its dependencies in cmake projects. The Orocos toolchain installs a cmake config file in <prefix>/lib/cmake/orocos-rtt/orocos-rtt-config.cmake which you can use by calling find_package(OROCOS-RTT). We are preparing more helper macros to ease component and application building.
When using autoproj to configure the build, the default install directory defaults to orocos-toolchain/install. The autoproj build is configured in the autoproj/ subdirectory of the toolchain.

Windows targets are better supported than ever, although broader testing wouldn't hurt. Xenomai, Mac OS-X and Gnu/Linux are very well supported. We need more feedback from users on the RTAI/LXRT front.

Adding primitives to TaskContexts has been greatly simplified. In most cases, no helper objects are necessary. Take a look at the examples or documentation how properties, operations and ports are added to a TaskContext. The rtt2-converter script rewrites all your 1.x components to use the new syntax.

The Data Flow has been completely reworked. Buffering and locking policies are now set on a per-connection basis. The only two port types that exist are RTT::InputPort and RTT::OutputPort. The rtt-conversion tool renames all your ports and does a best-effort to discover to what it should be converted.
Marshalling (XML reading/writing of parameters) and scripting have become plugins. Only components that make use of it will allocate memory for these services. (See also Caveats).

The term Toolkit has been renamed to Typekit. Users should not write typekits themselves and use the typegen tool instead. It parses C++ headers and generates type info, corba and mqueue transports from it. A typekit generator for ROS is also available, separately from typegen.

Orocos knows the complete structure of your registered data types, and provides some default functions for serializing (XML) and accessing (scripting) these structures. In case you need to extend this functionality (like adding operators or an alternative XML representation) you still need to hand-code these functions, since typegen has no knowledge for generating such code.

Reading and writing ports that are connected to ports of components in other processes is always real-time. A back-ground thread will do the non-real-time dispatching of the port data over the network.
Corba transport typekits (former toolkits) are now automatically generated from plain C++ headers with the typegen tool.

A new transport for hard real-time data flow communication between components on the same host but in different processes has been added. It is based on POSIX MQueues and is supported on the GNU/Linux and Xenomai targets.
A code generator for ROS typekits is available, which turns ROS messages into Orocos types, which can be used in scripting and data flow communication.

It is currently in beta-development, but no known issues exist at the moment. It allows to connect Orocos components to ROS nodes, without the need for a special deployer. The standard OCL DeploymentComponent can set up these connections.
Corba transport typekits (former toolkits) are now automatically generated from plain C++ headers with the typegen tool. Do not hand-write custom typekits or transports for CORBA.
This release is binary incompatible with OCL &oldversion;.x. You need to recompile all your applications in order to upgrade to this release.

Most components have been removed from this library. Only these modules remain:
reporting
deployment
helloworld
ocl
bin
taskbrowser
logging
timer
All removed components are to be picked up by users that wish to maintain them. A central place for looking up such repositories will be made available on the Orocos Toolchain home page.

Creating component libraries has slightly changed. You must now use the -DRTT_COMPONENT flag during compiling instead of -DOCL_DLL_EXPORT. The latter is still accepted during this release but may break in future releases.
Also the header ocl/ComponentLoader.hpp has been renamed to ocl/Component.hpp. The rtt2-converter script takes care of this renaming.
It is no longer required to link with OCL if you create a component using -DRTT_COMPONENT and including <ocl/Component.hpp>. Your libraries only need to link with the RTT library.

The DeploymentComponent expects components and plugins to be installed in a specific directory structure. Each directory to look for components must be mentioned in the RTT_COMPONENT_PATH environment variable or DeploymentComponent property. For each directory in RTT_COMPONENT_PATH, the subdirectories plugins/ and types/ are searched for plugins and typekits respectively. You may set RTT_COMPONENT_PATH similar to how the PATH variable is set on your Operating System.

For example: RTT_COMPONENT_PATH=/opt/2.0/lib/orocos:/opt/2.0/lib/testing # Searches for components in '/opt/2.0/lib/orocos/*.[so|dll]' and '/opt/2.0/lib/testing/*.[so|dll]' # Searches for plugins in '/opt/2.0/lib/orocos/plugins/*.[so|dll]' and '/opt/2.0/lib/testing/plugins/*.[so|dll]' # Searches for typekits in '/opt/2.0/lib/orocos/types/*.[so|dll]' and '/opt/2.0/lib/testing/types/*.[so|dll]'

You can no longer import() 'normal' libraries into the process in order to resolve missing symbols in your components. You need to link your component to the correct library, or create a plugin for that library.

You can now specify connection policies for data flow connections between ports. The 1.x scheme still exists, but for each connection name, you can specify if it needs to be buffered, which protocol to use, etc. See RTT::ConnPolicy.

You can now create streamed connections, which creates a stream to or from a port. This is used by the POSIX mqueue transport and the ROS transport, which are connection-less transports. The DeploymentComponent will automatically try to create a stream if a connection only has one port.
Deployment now also works on the Windows platform.
The TaskBrowser can be compiled with the 'editline' library, which is a BSD-licensed alternative to the 'readline' libary, which is GPL.

The TaskBrowser can now create new variables (for examplevar int i = 3, which are stored in the current component, it accepts multiple assignments, and shows and completes the data structure of variables.

The ReportingComponent is more efficient and can quickly serialize data due to better introspection mechanisms in the RTT. It can work event-based (when new data is to be logged) or sample-based (scans all ports on a regular basis).

appendix.title: About Orocos
appendix.para: Please send your Orocos questions to orocos-users at lists.mech.kuleuven.be .
These pages are maintained by the Orocos team.

For questions related to the use of the Orocos Software, please consult these web pages and the Orocos RTT manuals. If that fails, the orocos-dev at lists.mech.kuleuven.be mailing list might help. Please send comments on these web pages and the development of Orocos to our developer mailing list at orocos-dev at lists.mech.kuleuven.be . All of our lists have public archives ( dev public archive ) .
